required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Low-dose S-Ketamine and Postpartum Depression in Parturients With Prenatal Depression
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Low-dose S-Ketamine on Incidence of Postpartum Depression in Parturients With Prenatal Depression: A Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Postpartum depression is common in mothers early after childbirth and produces harmful effects not only on mothers, but also on infants and young children. Parturients with prenatal depression are at increased risk of postpartum depression. Low-dose s-ketamine can be used for antidepressant therapy. We hypothesize that low-dose s-ketamine has a therapeutic effect on parturients with prenatal depression. This study is designed to investigate whether low-dose s-ketamine administered after childbirth can reduce the incidence of postpartum depression in parturients with prenatal depression.

detailed_description.textblock:
Postpartum depression refers to maternal depression developed early after childbirth, with reported incidences varied from 10% to 20%. The development of postpartum depression produces harmful effects not only on mothers, but also on infants and young children. Prenatal depression or high depression score is an independent risk factor for the development of postpartum depression.
Ketamine is a commonly used general anesthetic. In addition, low-dose ketamine is recommended for antidepressant therapy. S-ketamine is more potent as an anaesthetic and might also have a better antidepressive effect. We hypothesize that low-dose s-ketamine has a therapeutic effect on parturients with prenatal depression. However, evidences in this aspect are insufficient. The purpose of this study is to investigate whether low-dose s-ketamine administered after childbirth can reduce the incidence of postpartum depression in parturients with prenatal depression.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: The incidence of depression at 42 days after childbirth.
primary_outcome.description: Postpartum depression at 42 days is diagnosed by using the Mini-International Neuropsychiatric Interview-Version 6.0 (MINI-V6.0) by a psychiatrist.

secondary_outcome.measure: The score of depression at 7 and 42 days after childbirth.
secondary_outcome.description: The score of depression at 7 and 42 days after childbirth is assessed by using the Edinburgh Postpartum Depression Scale (EPDS). This is a 10-item self-report questionnaire; each item is rated from 0 to 3 denoting the increasing severity of symptoms, resulting in a total score range from 0 to 30, with higher score indicating more severe depression.

secondary_outcome.measure: The score of pain at 1, 7 and 42 days after childbirth.
secondary_outcome.description: The score of pain at 1, 7 and 42 days after childbirth is assessed by using a Numeric Rating Scale (an 11-point scale where 0 indicates no pain and 10 the worst pain).

secondary_outcome.measure: The proportion of neonates with breast-feeding.
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of neonates with breast-feeding.

secondary_outcome.measure: The incidence of postpartum complications within 42 days after childbirth.
secondary_outcome.description: The incidence of postpartum complications within 42 days after childbirth.

secondary_outcome.measure: The incidence of neonatal disease within 42 days after birth.
secondary_outcome.description: The incidence of neonatal disease within 42 days after birth.

arm_group.description: Low-dose s-ketamine (0.2 mg/kg in 20 ml normal saline) is intravenously infused in 40 minutes after childbirth.
Placebo (20 ml normal saline) is intravenously infused in 40 minutes after childbirth.

intervention.description: S-ketamine (0.2 mg/kg in 20 ml normal saline) is administered by intravenous infusion in 40 minutes after childbirth.
Placebo (20 ml normal saline) is administered by intravenous infusion in 40 minutes after childbirth.
